/home

userid
|
+---Help
|    |
|    +---Node 1
|    +---Nod 2 
|
+---UserData
    |
    +---Userfile1
    +---UserFile 2

Only the contents of the UserData folder can be altered by the user. At the start of the user session I issue a 

tar -zcpf /dev/null -C /home/userid -g /home/snar/userid.snar /home/userid/UserData

to create an initial snar snapshot of the user's files.

When the user terminates her session I issue

tar -zcf /home/userdata/userid.tgz -g /home/snar/userid.snar /home/userid/UserData";

to create a differential snapshot of what has changed during the session. No worries so far. Then when the user starts a repeat session I do the following

  1. First reload the base profile snapshot which is shared by all users working with that profile
  2. Locate the differential snapshot for userid I created earlier.

Now here is the problem. userid.tgz contains the entire folder structure for that user. In order to simply inject user modified files into the profile snapshot image that has just been reloaded I have three options

  • Issue

    cd / && tar zxf /home/userdata/userid.tgz

    which would place the extracted contents in the drive root. Which is probably ok since it contains everything starting from home downwards. But this leaves me feeling a bit uncomfortable.

  • Extract the archive to a temporary location say

    tar -zxf /home/userdata/userid.tgz /home/tmp/userid

and then issue 

cp -ur /home/tmp/userid /home/userid

to simply update everything that has changed.

  • Use

    rsync -rvf /home/tmp/userid /home/userid

to achieve the same result.

I have tried the first & the third method and could easily try the second. However, they all leave me with the feeling that I might be going about this the wrong way through an ignorance of the right way of doing things. I would much appreciate any input on whether any of these methods are right for the job and, if not, how else I could accomplish the desired result

" OwnerUserId="1077485" LastEditorUserId="1077485" LastEditDate="2015-03-07T12:41:39.240" LastActivityDate="2015-03-07T12:41:39.240" Title="Restore from differential archive" Tags="" AnswerCount="0" CommentCount="0"/> " OwnerUserId="3013146" LastEditorUserId="3013146" LastEditDate="2015-03-07T12:35:23.733" LastActivityDate="2015-03-07T12:35:23.733" Title="Open New Window using h:commandButton in JSF" Tags="" AnswerCount="0" CommentCount="2"/> " OwnerUserId="1406271" LastActivityDate="2015-03-07T13:41:55.173" Title="preg_match - what's wrong with this code?" Tags="" AnswerCount="2" CommentCount="1"/>

Now, below are the files, I wrote.

server:

 #include<stdio.h>
 #include<stdlib.h>
 #include<string.h>
 #include<unistd.h>
 #include<arpa/inet.h>
 #include<sys/types.h>
 #include<netinet/in.h>
 #include<sys/socket.h>


#define MAX_LEN 100
#define PORTNUM 2300

int main( int argc , char * argv[] )
{
char msg[MAX_LEN + 1];
int len;

struct sockaddr_in dest;

struct sockaddr_in serv;

int mysocket;
socklen_t socket = sizeof ( struct sockaddr_in );
memset ( &serv , 0 , sizeof (serv));

serv.sin_family = AF_INET;

serv.sin_addr.s_addr = htonl(INADDR_ANY);

serv.sin_port = htons (PORTNUM);

mysocket = socket (AF_INET , SOCK_STREAM , 0);

bind (mysocket , (struct sockaddr*)&serv , sizeof (struct sockaddr));

listen (mysocket , 1);

int consocket = accept ( mysocket , (struct sockaddr *)&dest , &socksize);

while (consocket)
{
    printf("Incoming Connection from %s - Secding Welcome\n",inet_ntoa(dest.sin_addr));

    len = recv ( mysocket , msg , MAX_LEN , 0);
    msg[MAX_LEN] = '\0';

    printf("Received the text %s, echoing it back\n",msg);

    send( consocket , msg , len , 0 );

    close (consocket);

    consocket = accept (mysocket , (struct sockaddr *)&dest , &socksize);
}

close(mysocket);

return EXIT_SUCCESS;
}

Client: 

#include<stdio.h>
#include<stdlib.h>
#include<string.h>
#include<arpa/inet.h>
#include<sys/types.h>
#include<sys/socket.h>
#include<netinet/in.h>

#define PORTNUM 2300
#define MAX_LEN 100

int main( int argc , char * argv[] )
{
char msg[MAX_LEN + 1];
int len;
char buffer[MAX_LEN + 1];

struct sockaddr_in dest;

int mysocket = socket( AF_INET , SOCK_STREAM , 0);

memset(&dest , 0 , sizeof(dest));

dest.sin_family = AF_INET;
dest.sin_addr.s_addr = htonl (INADDR_LOOPBACK) ;
dest.sin_port = htons (PORTNUM);

connect ( mysocket , (struct sockaddr * )&dest , sizeof(struct sockaddr));

printf("Connected to the server, Please Enter your Message:\n");
scanf("%s",msg);

printf ("Sending the message : %s to the server.\nPlease wait....\n",msg);

send ( mysocket , msg , strlen(msg) , 0);

printf("The message has been sent.\nWaiting for the Server's reply....\n");

len = recv( mysocket , buffer , MAX_LEN , 0 );
buffer[len] = '\0';

printf("Received %s from the server.\n",buffer);

close(mysocket);

return EXIT_SUCCESS;
}

I get the following error, when compiling:

cc -o assignserver assignserver.c
assignserver.c: In function main:
assignserver.c:32:20: error: called object socket is not a function
assignserver.c:38:66: error: socksize undeclared (first use in this function)
assignserver.c:38:66: note: each undeclared identifier is reported only once for each function it appears in

Now, I know that socksize variable is not defined in the file. But I overlooked it the last time and it worked for a one - way communication with no errors.

Working code:

Server:

#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <string.h>
#include <unistd.h>
#include <arpa/inet.h>
#include <sys/types.h>
#include <netinet/in.h>
#include <sys/socket.h>

#define PORTNUM 2300

int main ( int argc , char * argv[] )
{

    char * msg = "Hello World !\n";

    struct sockaddr_in dest;

    struct sockaddr_in serv;
    int mysocket;
    socklen_t socksize = sizeof (struct sockaddr_in);
    memset ( &serv , 0 , sizeof (serv));

    serv.sin_family = AF_INET;

    serv.sin_addr.s_addr = htonl(INADDR_ANY);

    serv.sin_port = htons (PORTNUM);

    mysocket = socket (AF_INET , SOCK_STREAM , 0);

    bind ( mysocket , (struct sockaddr *)&serv , sizeof (struct sockaddr) );

    listen (mysocket , 1);

    int consocket = accept (mysocket , (struct sockaddr *)&dest , &socksize);

    while (consocket)
    {
        printf("Incoming connection from %s - sending Welcome\n", inet_ntoa(dest.sin_addr));
        send(consocket,msg,strlen(msg),0);

        close (consocket);

        consocket = accept (mysocket , (struct sockaddr *)&dest , &socksize);
    }

    close(mysocket);

    return EXIT_SUCCESS;

}

This is working perfectly fine. It just relays a message to clients that connect to it. Can you please help find what the issue is? and why it worked the first time around ( in the second server code ). Also, I would be really happy if you can point me to a tutorial of some sorts where I can learn just the network programming aspect of the c programming language. Thank you in advance.

Edit 1: Formatting issues.

" OwnerUserId="968252" LastActivityDate="2015-03-07T13:01:15.120" Title="Async callbacks/promises running that protractor/webdriver is not aware of" Tags="" AnswerCount="0" CommentCount="1" FavoriteCount="1"/>

2) Another implementation with preg_replace_callback(), which is very reliable from my experience, just as an example:

$message = 'This is a text with 2 Youtube videos: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rxwMjB-Skao csassasas http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VWEwWECAokU Enf of text';

$reg_exUrl_youtube = "/(?:http(?:s)?:\/\/)?(?:www\.)?(?:youtu\.be\/|youtube\.com\/(?:(?:watch)?\?(?:.*&)?v(?:i)?=|(?:embed|v|vi|user)\/))([^\?&\"'> \r\n]+)(?![^<]*>)/";

$finalString = preg_replace_callback($reg_exUrl_youtube, function($matches) {
    return "<iframe title=\"{$matches[1]}\" class=\"youtube\" src=\"[qqqqq].youtube.com/embed/{$matches[1]}\" frameborder=\"0\" allowFullScreen></iframe>";
}, $message);

echo htmlentities($finalString);

Where rotZ is what I want to send, it is a "float" value. I need to put the " \n" on the end of the message so that it will be recognized as a full message on the PC. So far so good. Now I want to read this on my PC, which is achieved by:

  //BlueTooth
  String lineRead = "";
  try
  {
    lineRead = new String(sampleSPPServer.readFromDevice());
    if(lineRead != null && !lineRead.isEmpty())
    {
      String lineTransf = lineRead.replace("\n", "").replace("\r", "").replace(" ", "").replace("\"", "").trim();
      println("LineTransf: " + lineTransf);
      rotZ += 0.01*(Float.parseFloat(lineTransf));
      println("Zrotation: " + rotZ); //Never gets here, throws and error before...
    }
    else
      rotZ += 0;
  }
  catch(Exception e)
  {
    println("Exception: " + e);
  }

Which gives me the error:

NumberFormatException: invalid float value: "1.1400002"

In my code you can see I check for null, empty, etc. So that's not the problem. I've already tried:

  NumberFormat nf = NumberFormat.getInstance(Locale.US);
  rotZ += 0.01*(nf.parse(lineTransf).floatValue());

Got the same result... In stackoverflow there is a similar question: Here

There is one more strange thing, If I try the code:

  for(int i = 0; i < lineTransf.length(); i++)
    println(lineTransf.substring(i,1));

I get that the string's length is 19, but it only prints the first two and gives the message:

Exception: java.lang.StringIndexOutOfBoundsException: String index out of range: -1

Even more strange thing, when I did ctrl-c, ctrl-v on the number "1.1400002" that appears in the console, it only pastes "1" here on stack overflow. I know that the number is right, but somewhere the conversion is not. I think that's because the string is sent as a byte and read as a String, but how do I solve this problem? Thanks in advance!!

" OwnerUserId="4617935" LastActivityDate="2015-03-07T14:04:23.990" Title="(Java + Android) Parsing string to float strange error" Tags="" AnswerCount="2" CommentCount="0"/> Docker Volume Container approach: put your static assets in a DVC and mount that DVC in the main container so it's all pretty much "just one app container". You could use Docker Compose something like this:

appdata:
    image: busybox
    volumes:
        - /path/to/app/static
    command: echo "I'm just a volume container"
app:
    build: .
    volumes_from:
        - appdata
    command:

You can expand further by starting your container with a bootstrap script that copies initial static files into the destination path on startup. That way your app is guaranteed to always have a default set to get started, but you can add more static files as the app grows. For an example of this, pull the official Jenkins container and read /usr/local/bin/jenkins.sh.

}

?>

And at the dashboard you can do this if it's of client

<?php 
    ob_start();
    session_start();
    if(!isset($_SESSION['username']))
    {
        die('Please log in first');
    }
    unset($_SESSION['username']);

    */rest code*/

?>

And similarly for the dashboard of trainer

<?php 
    ob_start();
    session_start();
    if(!isset($_SESSION['tusername']))
    {
        die('Please log in first');
    }
    unset($_SESSION['tusername']);

    */rest code*/

?>

You are unsetting the session variable because if you will not do that then it will work only for the first time, because after that your session will set permanently Therefore you have to unset them
